title: Why I Did Pushups on Camera To Launch a Wellness Challenge
description: Even when it’s your product, leadership sometimes means getting a little uncomfortable.
content:
Even when it’s your product, leadership sometimes means getting a little uncomfortable.

Which felt a bit ironic, considering wellness is literally what we do. It’s our product. Our mission. Our reason for showing up. So naturally, when I saw the low engagement, my first instinct was frustration. But then I had a more honest thought: If people aren’t engaging, what am I doing to lead it?

Now, I’ve used video plenty of times before to rally the team. It’s one of my go-to tools, especially in a hybrid environment. And I’ve done a variety of fitness and endurances races, so people usually think I’m “the fit one.” But this wasn’t one of those moments. I’ve been recovering from an injury. This wellness challenge happened to land during a time when I hadn’t worked out in months. I wasn’t feeling like an athlete. I was feeling like someone whose body wasn’t quite ready, but whose team needed a little spark. So I threw on Eye of the Tiger, dropped to the floor, and recorded myself doing pushups. Grunts, forehead vein, bad lighting—everything stayed in. I didn’t write a script, and I didn’t overthink it.

What happened next was the point A couple hours later, two team members recorded their own videos. Within a day, the chat thread turned into a mini movement with people cheering each other on, firing off emojis, and trading jokes about sore muscles.

There’s a trap a lot of leaders fall into (me included), believing that our role is to point the way, and others will follow. Especially when the thing we’re pointing to is already built, branded, and rolled out with good intentions. When it’s your product, your challenge, or your initiative, you assume your enthusiasm is contagious. It isn’t. Not by default. You can’t always motivate from behind a keyboard. Sometimes, you’ve got to lead with action.

That doesn’t mean you have to be the loudest person in the room. But it does mean you need to be first, especially when what you’re asking is new, different, or just a little uncomfortable. It’s about going first (not going perfect) In hindsight, it wasn’t the video that worked. It was the willingness to be a little silly. A little human.

People joined because they saw effort. They saw someone willing to put themselves out there, even if the moment wasn’t peak performance. In fact, I think it helped that this was my first physical activity in months. It made it real. Approachable. Not a flex, just a start. Sometimes, going first means doing the thing that feels awkward. And sometimes it means doing the thing you used to be good at, but haven’t done in a while. Either way, it invites others in.
summary: The author of the Wellness Challenge explains why he used a video to motivate his team by doing pushups on camera, despite not feeling like an athlete and feeling frustrated at low engagement. He found this an opportunity to connect with his team, which he believes is their mission and their product. The video was used to motivate the team and inspired them to record their own videos and engage in the process. Despite not being the best at a professional level, the video's impact was seen as a powerful motivator who made the team feel more engaging and engaging. The author argues that leaders often fall into the trap of believing that their role is to point the way and others will follow, especially when their product is already established.
shortSummary: When I first launched a wellness challenge, I noticed low engagement, prompting me to record himself doing pushups and encourage others to participate, despite some physical struggles.

argos_summary: The article discusses the importance of leadership in fostering engagement, particularly in a wellness initiative. The author shares a personal experience of overcoming discomfort by recording a video of themselves doing pushups, which sparked participation among team members and created a supportive environment. It emphasizes that effective leadership often requires leading by example and being willing to be vulnerable, rather than simply relying on enthusiasm to motivate others.
